content.user_title: Automate Chrome and Debug Web Pages
content.value_statement: Browser automation is slow and error-prone with manual commands. This skill provides optimized patterns to automate Chrome, debug pages, capture screenshots, and inspect network requests through chrome-devtools-mcp server.
actual_capabilities: Navigate to URLs and manage browser tabs programmatically
Capture screenshots of web pages in PNG format
Execute JavaScript code on web pages
Inspect console messages and network requests
Debug web pages by taking content snapshots
Automate form filling and element clicking
limitations: Requires chrome-devtools-mcp server installation via MCP CLI
Only works with Google Chrome browser
Does not support Firefox, Safari, or other browsers
Requires Chrome to be installed on the system

best_practices: Use shell mode with multiple commands in one pipeline for faster execution
Always use --isolated flag to prevent browser profile lock conflicts
Include timeout wrapper to prevent hanging commands
anti_patterns: Running separate shell sessions for each command causes browser lock issues
Skipping the cleanup step leads to browser already running errors
Using npx instead of bunx may cause compatibility issues

faq.question: Which browsers are supported?
faq.answer: Only Google Chrome is supported. The MCP server uses Chrome DevTools protocol directly.

faq.question: What is the maximum screenshot size?
faq.answer: Screenshots support full page capture. Large pages may take longer to process.

faq.question: How do I connect to an existing Chrome instance?
faq.answer: Start Chrome with --remote-debugging-port=9222 flag and use --browserUrl parameter.

faq.question: Is my browsing data safe?
faq.answer: The --isolated flag uses temporary browser profiles. Avoid visiting sensitive sites during automation.

faq.question: Why am I getting browser lock errors?
faq.answer: Previous browser instances are holding the profile. Run pkill -9 -f chrome-devtools-mcp first.

faq.question: How does this compare to Puppeteer or Playwright?
faq.answer: This uses Chrome DevTools MCP protocol directly. It is lighter weight but less feature-rich than those tools.
